title: Australian Reptile Park films video opening funnel web spider sac
text:
This is the horrifying moment more than a hundred deadly funnel web spiders burst out from egg sac.

The footage from Australian Reptile Park, on the New South Wales Central Coast, showed the park's head of spiders Kane Christensen open the sac with a scalpel.

Tiny - but highly venomous - baby spiders are then seen flowing out of the white pouch.

The footage from Australian Reptile Park, on the NSW Central Coast, showed the park's Head of Spiders Kane Christensen open the sac with a scapel

IDENTIFYING FUNNEL WEB SPIDERS Eyes closely grouped

No obvious body pattern

Lower lip studded with short, blunt spines

Shiny carapace

Males had a modified second leg

Four spinnerets - the largest has the last part longer rather than wider Source: Australian Museum

The video was filmed as part of the wildlife sanctuary launching its spider container - a room filled with 3,000 funnel webs.

The spiders are then milked for their venom so antivenom can be made.

Mr Christensen said: 'Our aim is to milk 3,000 funnel web spiders annually to send the raw venom we milk to Seqirus, who create the antivenom for hospitals around Australia.

'We're so excited to call this a step in a right direction and a true indication on how hard our keepers are working.'

Hundreds of tiny spiders proceeded to run out of the sac. They climbed over each other in an attempt to get out after being confined in the sac

He added that it was still important for more funnel webs to be handed in to the park.

Mr Christensen said: 'Catching funnel webs can be a safe practice for sensible adults. When collecting spiders adults should be equipped with a spider safety kit including a glass jar with air holes in the lid, and a plastic ruler to guide the spider into the jar.

'We encourage parents to educate children that should they locate a spider of any kind that they find a parent immediately and do not try and touch the spider with their hands.'

The spiders are often found in shady, sheltered and damp places.

They have been found in shoes and around pools in the past.
description: The footage from Australian Reptile Park, on the NSW Central Coast, showed the sac opened with a scapel and tongs - allowing for hundreds of deadly creatures to crawl out.
authors: Claudia Poposki For Daily Mail Australia
